subject: Margin decoration technique — block-printed (kalıp baskı) vs. battal ebru

primary_hypothesis.description: Decorative paper produced by pressing a carved wooden block onto the paper surface. The block carries ink/pigment on its raised surfaces, transferring a repeating pattern. The arkeoloji_01454 pattern shows large overlapping circles/ovals (~5-8 cm diameter) filled with fine branching stipple texture, separated by colored vein networks.

alternative_hypothesis.description: A highly controlled variant of stone marbling where the ebru artist manipulated the bath (possibly via systematic size-drop placement) to produce regular cell structures. This would be an unusual and undocumented subtype of battal ebru.

favoring_block_print: Regular repeating cell grid pattern — overlapping circles/ovals arranged systematically, too uniform for marbling where pigments float freely
Uniform internal branching stipple texture identical across ALL cells on each page — battal ebru produces unique internal structures per pigment pool
Same basic pattern structure replicated across 9+ margin pages (pp002-010) — true battal ebru produces a unique, unrepeatable pattern every pull
Consistent cell size (~5-8 cm) throughout each page — battal ebru produces cells of wildly varying sizes
Sharp cell boundaries with consistent vein width — battal ebru boundaries are diffuse and irregular
Pattern alignment differs between left and right pages at the spine (p001) — consistent with two separate block impressions on separate sheets
Pattern has consistent directional orientation — battal ebru has no inherent directionality
favoring_battal_ebru: Polychrome pigment pooling at vein junctions (blue, green, red-brown, ochre mix) — harder to achieve with a single block pass
Some cell-to-cell size variation (not perfectly identical)
Organic curvature in some vein boundaries rather than rigid straight edges
neutral_or_ambiguous: Two distinct paper color variants (cool grey-blue pp002-008; warmer greenish-sage pp009-010) — could indicate different ink batches (block-print) OR different ebru bath preparations
Fine white branching stipple inside cells — could be carved block texture OR dendritic crystallization from sizing-pigment interaction on bath

tests_required: Raking light examination: block impressions leave faint relief/depression marks on the paper surface visible under oblique illumination
Fiber cross-section microscopy: block-printed pigment sits ON the surface; ebru pigment penetrates INTO the fibers from the bath
UV fluorescence: different binding media (block ink vs. ebru gall) may fluoresce differently
Comparison with known Ottoman block-printed papers in the İstanbul Arkeoloji Müzeleri collection or Topkapı Palace Library
physical_examination_protocol.note: The İstanbul Arkeoloji Müzeleri's own library location makes physical examination logistically feasible

corpus_significance: If confirmed as block-printed, arkeoloji_01454 would be the FIRST block-printed decorated paper (kalıplı kâğıt) in the entire corpus of 85+ records. All other decorated papers in the corpus are marbled (ebru subtypes), colored/dyed (mülevven), gold-sprinkled (zerefşân), halkar (painted), or gold-worked (zerkârî). Block-printed papers represent a distinct production tradition with different workshop contexts, tools, and chronological distribution than ebru.
